caseTitle: REX V AKPAN UDO UDO ESSIEN
summary: In this 1939 West African Court of Appeal case, Akpan Udo Udo Essien appealed his murder conviction for the killing of Udo Udo Umoren. The appellant was identified as the person who sold the victim's bicycle shortly after the attack. Although the trial judge incorrectly characterized the appellant's post-arrest statement as a 'complete confession,' the appellate court found overwhelming evidence of guilt, including the appellant's own statement implicating himself in the crime, blood-stained clothing, and a dying declaration identifying the assailants. The court concluded that the mischaracterization did not affect the verdict, as the evidence was conclusive, and dismissed the appeal.
legalKeywords: West African Court of Appeal Rules Rule 47
citations: Rex v Akpan Udo Udo Essien, WACA/5, 3rd March 1939
rationaleHighlights: Trial judge mischaracterized statement as 'complete confession' but error was not material
Appellant's statement implicated him in the crime despite not admitting direct perpetration
Dying declaration corroborated by circumstantial evidence
Blood-stained clothing linked appellant to the crime
Overwhelming prosecution evidence rendered misdirection harmless
No serious defence was presented at trial
Finding of guilt was inevitable regardless of error
Burden on appellant to show probable effect of misdirection not met
